VOL. XX.XI, No. 57

PLAYSHOP COMPLETES
SUCCESSFUL SEASON
Enjoys Best Year of Its History,
Says Uhler
MANY CASTS ENTERTAINED
Drama of Five Countries Is
Presented During Year
"The past season has been the
most successful in the history of the
Homewood Playshop," said Dr.
John Earle. Uhler at a business
meeting of that organization last
Saturday night. This statement is
more fully appreciated when one
learns that during'the past year the
Playshop has been able to pay off
its entire debt to the University; it
has given more performances than
ever before wiih larger audiences
and more favorable newspaper comment, and it has had at teas, in the
lecture stand, and on -the stage both
dramatists and actors of repute in
theatrical circles, throughout the
world.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD. JUNE 13, 1927

SENIOR BANQUET OPENS ELABORATE
FESTIVTIES OF FIFTH JUNE WEEK
Ushered in by the Senior Banquet
at the Baltimore Country Club
Thurs'day night, the festivities bid
fair to eclipse any previous celebration, whether of a similar or of a
different nature.
For many students this week of
unalloyed pleasure is the land of
dreams toward which they have
toiled over the long winding trail
of a year of study, and through the
long, sleepless nights .during and
preceding examinations. For them
the night of waiting is gone, and
they have reached, with their
friends, a real dream day.

RODGERS ELECTED
0. D. K. PRESIDENT
I. Evans Rodgers was elected president of Omicron Delta
Kappa and C. Gardner Mallonee, vice-president at a meeting of this honorary society
held last week.
At the same meeting Leonard Dalsemer was chosen
treasurer and Charles McElfresh, secretary. These men
succeed Henry Jarrett, Larkin
Farinholt, Max Cone and Eugene O'Dunne who were officers of this organization during the past season.

minds of the undergraduates.
Many of the members of the faculty generously deign to
tolerate the undergraduate students. Some of them are less vigorous in the expression of their feeling than others, but that is
because they happen to be of kindlier natures. The more disdainful are openly sarcastic.
• This mournful, pessimistic tone may not be in keeping with
the jovial, carefree atmosphere of June Week, but it does reflect
the mean attitude among the undergraduates. Far be it from us
to invoke the Great God Rah-rah, but nevertheless we do express
a fervent, but none too hopeful, wish that the graduation of the
Class of 1927 does not really mean a definite cocaining of undergraduate life. As long as the College of Arts and Sciences remains an entity, undergraduate life and activities should live on.

News comes to us front Washington State College that the married
men are smarter than the single
ones. The problem for us to decide
is whether the most intelligent men
yet married—or whether getting
married leads to a higher intelliqC11CC.
* * *
Recent reports give us the new,
that Yale, Vermont, and the University of Pennsylvania have entered into a non-scouting agreement
for the football season of 1927. A
similar agreement among Southern
colleges and Maryland colleges in
particular might be advocated.
* * *
From the Ohio State Lantern
comes the news that the card sharp
is the latest grafter to visit the fraternity houses of that campus.
"Surely, I teach you how to tufn
a jack every time in seven up; make
cards disappear, beat a perfect
bridge hand and many others. Six
tricks for a dollar."

THE JOHNS FIOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, JUNE 13. 1927
REPORT SHOWS ACTIVITIES
COUNCIL'S BUSINESS
HAS INCREASED
More Money Has Passed Through the
Hands of Treasurer This Year
Than Ever Before

According to the report presented to the Student Activities Council by Larkin Farinholt, its president, more funds have passed
through the hands of the Student
Activities Council than in any previous year. The cash balance remaining this June amounts to over
two thousand dollars, which is distributed among the various activities in amounts varying from $2.36,
the Debating Council balance, to
$644.82, the .NEws-LETTER balance.
The publications, however, still
have printers' bills outstanding.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, JUNE 13, 1927

HOPKINS TEAMWORK NETS
FIRST EDITOR OF NEWS-LETTER
DESCRIBES FOUNDING OF PAPER
ANOTHER STICK CROWN
Thirty years ago the Johns Hopkins NEWS-LETTER was published
for the first time by three enterprising students—James M. Thomson,
'97, Edgeworth Smith,'98, and Herman Shuter, '97. From a small, intermittent literary sheet, the paper
has grown into a semi-weekly news
organ which holds a definite place
on the campus.
It was because of. the interest of
this first staff and because of their
belief that the University needed a
paper that the NEWS-LETTER put
forth its root into the campus soil.
James M. Thomson, the first Editor-in-Chief, is, to our knowledge,
the only editor who has followed
Mr.

publishing as a profession.

Thomson is publisher of the New
Orleans Morning Tribune, The New
Orleans Item, and The Item-Tribune. At the request of the editor,
Mr. Thomson has sent the NEWS-

LETTER some interesting facts concerning the first issues of the paper
and his connection with them. His
letter reads as follows:
Dear Sir:
Your letter reaches me on
my return to the city after
several weeks of absence.
I was .identified with the
founding of the NEws-LET-

TER, and was in the class of
'97, as was Herman Shuter,
business manager of the paper.
Edgeworth Smith was in the
class of '98. The name of the
paper, NEWS-LETTER, was his
idea. I understand that Shuter died out in the Philippines.
He was a very attractive fellow and very popular with his
classmates.
I was, of course, very enthusiastic about the paper. Smith
and I went one Sunday afternoon to lay the project before
the Hem. Daniel Coit Gilman,
president of the university, a
great man and a great educator.
Several attempts had been
made prior . to our effort to
found a students' paper in the
college. I think that our predecessors had gone about the
matter through petition to the
faculty or through some demand to exercise the right of

The

free printing guaranteed under
the Constitution.
I know that I was considerably frightened, and I imagine
that Dr. Gilman must have
thought Smith and I were two
mild youths who could do little
harm with a newspaper. At
any rate, he told us that he saw
no objection to our starting the
paper but would take the matter up with the authorities and
would let us know definitely at
a later date. No objection
was presented and the paper
was launched.
I do not need to tell students
at Hopkins who are having
their first experience with
printers' ink of the thrill which
Smith and Shuter and I experienced when the first issue
of the NEWS-LETTER came
from the presses.
I think we ran the paper for
somthing like half a year, and
it is My recollection that it was
forty dollars in debt when I
severed connection with it on
graduating from the college.
There must have been a need
for it, because it has lived.
When I last saw an issue of
the NEWS-LETTER it had
grown to a very healthy size.
Smith worked with printers'
ink for some time. He went
into the advertising business
and was connected with the
Army and Navy Journal.
When I last heard of him he
was a successful real estate
man in New York City.
Shuter was a lovable fellow
and Smith was one of the most
attractive and lovable boys that
I have ever known. He had
quite a talent for music, for
drawing and for the arts.
Printers' ink always exercised a great fascination for
me. I had my first experience
with the NEWS-LETTER. I was
preparing to study law; but felt
so strongly the desire to work
for a newspaper that I quit
law, went to Washington and
began newspaper work as a reporter
Post.

on

the

Washington

I have been at news-

paper work ever since.
With kindest regards, I am,
Sincerely yours,

JAMES

M. THOMSON.

PLAYSHOP COMPLETES
SUCCESSFUL SEASON
Enjoys Best Year of Its History,
Says Uhler
MANY CASTS ENTERTAINED
Drama of Five Countries Is
Presented During Year
"The past season has been the
most successful in the history of the
Homewood Playshop," said Dr.
John Earle. Uhler at a business
meeting of that organization last
Saturday night. This statement is
more fully appreciated when one
learns that during'the past year the
Playshop has been able to pay off
its entire debt to the University; it
has given more performances than
ever before wiih larger audiences
and more favorable newspaper comment, and it has had at teas, in the
lecture stand, and on -the stage both
dramatists and actors of repute in
theatrical circles, throughout the
world.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD. JUNE 13, 1927

SENIOR BANQUET OPENS ELABORATE
FESTIVTIES OF FIFTH JUNE WEEK
Ushered in by the Senior Banquet
at the Baltimore Country Club
Thurs'day night, the festivities bid
fair to eclipse any previous celebration, whether of a similar or of a
different nature.
For many students this week of
unalloyed pleasure is the land of
dreams toward which they have
toiled over the long winding trail
of a year of study, and through the
long, sleepless nights .during and
preceding examinations. For them
the night of waiting is gone, and
they have reached, with their
friends, a real dream day.

RODGERS ELECTED
0. D. K. PRESIDENT
I. Evans Rodgers was elected president of Omicron Delta
Kappa and C. Gardner Mallonee, vice-president at a meeting of this honorary society
held last week.
At the same meeting Leonard Dalsemer was chosen
treasurer and Charles McElfresh, secretary. These men
succeed Henry Jarrett, Larkin
Farinholt, Max Cone and Eugene O'Dunne who were officers of this organization during the past season.

the mean attitude among the undergraduates. Far be it from us
to invoke the Great God Rah-rah, but nevertheless we do express
a fervent, but none too hopeful, wish that the graduation of the
Class of 1927 does not really mean a definite cocaining of undergraduate life. As long as the College of Arts and Sciences remains an entity, undergraduate life and activities should live on.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, JUNE 13, 1927

HOPKINS TEAMWORK NETS
FIRST EDITOR OF NEWS-LETTER
DESCRIBES FOUNDING OF PAPER
ANOTHER STICK CROWN
Thirty years ago the Johns Hopkins NEWS-LETTER was published
for the first time by three enterprising students—James M. Thomson,
'97, Edgeworth Smith,'98, and Herman Shuter, '97. From a small, intermittent literary sheet, the paper
has grown into a semi-weekly news
organ which holds a definite place
on the campus.
It was because of. the interest of
this first staff and because of their
belief that the University needed a
paper that the NEWS-LETTER put
forth its root into the campus soil.
James M. Thomson, the first Editor-in-Chief, is, to our knowledge,
the only editor who has followed
Mr.

publishing as a profession.

Thomson is publisher of the New
Orleans Morning Tribune, The New
Orleans Item, and The Item-Tribune. At the request of the editor,
Mr. Thomson has sent the NEWS-

LETTER some interesting facts concerning the first issues of the paper
and his connection with them. His
letter reads as follows:
Dear Sir:
Your letter reaches me on
my return to the city after
several weeks of absence.
I was .identified with the
founding of the NEws-LET-

TER, and was in the class of
'97, as was Herman Shuter,
business manager of the paper.
Edgeworth Smith was in the
class of '98. The name of the
paper, NEWS-LETTER, was his
idea. I understand that Shuter died out in the Philippines.
He was a very attractive fellow and very popular with his
classmates.
I was, of course, very enthusiastic about the paper. Smith
and I went one Sunday afternoon to lay the project before
the Hem. Daniel Coit Gilman,
president of the university, a
great man and a great educator.
Several attempts had been
made prior . to our effort to
found a students' paper in the
college. I think that our predecessors had gone about the
matter through petition to the
faculty or through some demand to exercise the right of

The

free printing guaranteed under
the Constitution.
I know that I was considerably frightened, and I imagine
that Dr. Gilman must have
thought Smith and I were two
mild youths who could do little
harm with a newspaper. At
any rate, he told us that he saw
no objection to our starting the
paper but would take the matter up with the authorities and
would let us know definitely at
a later date. No objection
was presented and the paper
was launched.
I do not need to tell students
at Hopkins who are having
their first experience with
printers' ink of the thrill which
Smith and Shuter and I experienced when the first issue
of the NEWS-LETTER came
from the presses.
I think we ran the paper for
somthing like half a year, and
it is My recollection that it was
forty dollars in debt when I
severed connection with it on
graduating from the college.
There must have been a need
for it, because it has lived.
When I last saw an issue of
the NEWS-LETTER it had
grown to a very healthy size.
Smith worked with printers'
ink for some time. He went
into the advertising business
and was connected with the
Army and Navy Journal.
When I last heard of him he
was a successful real estate
man in New York City.
Shuter was a lovable fellow
and Smith was one of the most
attractive and lovable boys that
I have ever known. He had
quite a talent for music, for
drawing and for the arts.
Printers' ink always exercised a great fascination for
me. I had my first experience
with the NEWS-LETTER. I was
preparing to study law; but felt
so strongly the desire to work
for a newspaper that I quit
law, went to Washington and
began newspaper work as a reporter
Post.

on

the

Washington

I have been at news-

paper work ever since.
With kindest regards, I am,
Sincerely yours,

JAMES

M. THOMSON.

rainy, muddy days to receive one

Degroot's reputation as a goal

On Saturday, May 7, came the
crucial test for the Jay twelve, the
struggle which decided whether the
Intercollegiate .Lacrosse
crown
would remain at Homewod for another year. In this hotly contested
struggle with Navy, witnessed by
7,000 fans as one of the greatest
lacrosse classics ever staged, Hopkins teamwork came through again
and showed the • largest lacrosse
crowd ever assembled that Hopkins
tactics and Hopkins teamwork could
not he vanquished.
Following the Navy contest, first
St. Johns and then Maryland, our
traditional enemies went down in
bitter defeat before the fast sticks
of the Hopkins twelve, and when
the lacrosse season came to a close
on May 21, once again the Johns
Hopkins lacrosse team was proclaimed National Intercollegiate
Champions.
